Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Modes in Random Media and Tissue Characterization
Award.AbstractNarration: Nontechnical abstract:<br/>Understanding wave propagation in random systems is a fundamental problem with myriad applications. This work aims to show that all wave phenomena can be reduced to simple resonance properties. The role of resonances in wave propagation will be explored in space and time in experiments, and in numerical simulations and analytical theory. It will be shown that key aspects of waves in complex systems can be described in terms of a simple sum. These findings will be utilized to characterize transport in novel systems such as photonic topological insulators. The project includes development of a new and hopefully very impactful medical imaging technique for thin sections based on a spatial map of the transmission time. These studies have implications for medical imaging, telecommunications, resource exploration, and photonic devices.<br/><br/>Technical abstract: <br/>This projects seeks to provide a simple and comprehensive understanding of the statistics of modes and their role in wave propagation in random systems. Early work by Wigner and Dyson on the statistics of resonances, variously known as energy levels, eigenstates, quasi-normal modes, or simply as modes, focused on the probability distribution of level spacings and widths in nuclear scattering. But in open non-Hermitian systems, modes are not orthogonal, and it is the correlation between them that has the greatest impact on wave transport and energy deposition inside random systems. The role of modes in wave propagation will be explored in space and time in microwave and optical experiments, and in numerical simulations and analytical theory. The correlation between modes leads to destructive interference between modes and greatly suppresses transmission while leading to spatial and spectral correlation of the energy density within disordered media. Though the interference between modes is crucial, it was recently found that key dynamical variables, such as the transmission time, density of states and the sum of energy deposited in the sample for unit flux incident in all channels can be described as an incoherent sum over modes even in systems with dissipation and gain. These results will be utilized to characterize the limits of robust propagation along the domain wall between metacrystals with different Chern numbers in topological insulators. The project includes development of a new medical imaging modality for thin sections based on a spatial map of the transmission time, which is equal to the spectral derivative of the phase of the transmitted field. Finally, the simple functional form for the derivative of the phase will be explored as an approach to analyzing the field into the underlying modes. The results of these studies are relevant to both classical and quantum waves.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project expanded our understanding of the interaction of waves with disordered and periodic structures. Results are obtained in microwave measurements, numerical simulations, and random matrix theory.

We demonstrated that all wave properties can be described in terms of resonances of the medium even at points close to the source of the wave exciting the material. We discovered that net transmission can vanish in disordered systems and that the transmission time diverges as such points are approached. This may present a new ultrasensitive method for probing structural change. 

The transmission and conductance in disordered systems has be extensively characterized in terms of the set of transmission eigenvalues associated with transmission eigenchannels. Each eigenchannel corresponds to a particular shape of the incident wave. We have found that when materials are excited in a transmission eigenchannel, the average forward speed of the wave is the same at the output of the sample as it is in the input. This makes it possible to find the average energy density in a transmission eigenchannel on the sample’s surfaces. This in terms gives the diffusion coefficient, which is the ratio of the flux through the sample and the gradient of the energy density in the sample. Thus the nature of both steady-state and pulsed transmission can be determined from the interplay of two sets of parameters—the transmission eigenvalues and the eigenchannel velocities. This discovery allowed us to show that all propagation parameters in disordered samples, including the diffusion coefficient and the lengths in which the wave is scattered, depends upon the overall dimensions of the sample in addition to the local characteristics of the disordered material. This provides a deeper understanding of the way wave propagation changes as the dimensions of the sample change.

We also showed that pulses can move along the edges of moderately disordered two-dimensional materials, known as topological insulators, and be transmitted without change in shape.

We showed that the statistics of waves within samples of any dimension are independent of the detailed structure of a material and depend only on the net strengths of distributed scattering and reflection between the observation point and each of the boundaries.
